body: You can do a rebase http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-resolve-conflict-with-master
something is wrong when I do rebase your mxnet.

I do fetch your mxnet, but my repository is changed to my older version one when I do rebase.
really strange.
I have pushed the newest code to my forked mxnet, can you check it?
I need a little time to figure out the strange problem of rebase.
Can I do merge?

The general instruction is here http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-resolve-conflict-with-master 

If you find files with conflicts, edit the files and merge the conflict, and do a git add as indicated in the instruction
the situation is: I have commit a lot in my local repository, when I rebase to your newest master, my current work directory content is updated to the first commit. What can I do?

Yes, this can be done by extending the https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/channel_op_common.h to add a concat dimension argument.

Note that mshadow's concat and slice support along arbitrary dimension. But we need to add it :)

Are you interested in contributing? Also note although mshadow is templated, we can either enumerate dim with template, or do some reshape trick, to reshape to a 3D tensor and concat on dim 1. So it is general for any dimension

Thanks;

The name of your label in dataiter should match that required by your linear regression output layer (by default it is 'out_label' in this case). The default name for labels in the data provider is `softmax_label` just for backward compatibility. You should be able to change the name when you construct the dataiter.

Another option is to create a `Variable` (just like `data`) and specify a name. For example, you can do 

``` python
label = mx.symbol.Variable('softmax_label')
# ...
out = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=fc1,label=label,name='out')
```

if you don't want to change the name of the data iter.

thanks, I didn't notice the lable name. 

And I found an example in R which don't need this label name, so I just follow this to write my Python demo. 

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/R-package/fiveMinutesNeuralNetwork.html#regression

```
# Define the input data
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
# A fully connected hidden layer
# data: input source
# num_hidden: number of neurons in this hidden layer
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)

# Use linear regression for the output layer
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)
```

Yes, we recently changed the API on Python side in order to support multiple input and output variables properly. The R side is still the old API that guess the label name based on a "_label" postfix.

with out [:] you are allocating a new ndarray (or numpy.ndarray) to store the results. This will hurt performance and sometimes correctness.
I would keep the [:] unless I really want to allocate a new array
Without [:], actually what was happened was the old ndarray is discard, and the variable now stores an float value in python. So the correctness of code depend on how you use it

@winstywang , the inputs don't have the same formula mode, so we cannot concat it. I'm writing the crop layer in python, just as(but not the same ) https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/1639

Just declare any input and weights in list_arguments ['input_1', 'input_2',...]
and when creating the symbol 
new_layer = NewLayer()
new_layer(input_1=x1, input_2=x2...)

@winstywang , Yeah, i got it, when more inputs, just as concat = mx.symbol.Concat(*[conv, pool])

Thanks for the suggestion. We do not yet have a C++ example so far(which is a bit shame as the main program is in c++), but you can find examples in
- Go https://github.com/jdeng/gomxnet
- python https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/predict/python/mxnet_predict.py and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/python/predict/mxnet_predict_example.py
- Java https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/526

All of these relies on a C API, so actually they are using C :)  I guess things can be done with opencv fairly easily, except that we did not have examples yet to put up a C++ example. Let us know if these examples make sense to you and if you are interested in contributing a C++ example

Thank you all.
I solve the problem by add numpy_batch_size=1,  param :

```
netPredict = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=gpus, symbol=fea_symbol, 
        numpy_batch_size=1,arg_params=arg,aux_params=aux, allow_extra_params=True)
```
please refer the doc [module-mxnet.optimizer](https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/model.html?highlight=optimizer#module-mxnet.optimizer)

private now, you may find Kaiming He's paper in constrain complexity
helpful.

> Hi,
> I am also working on deep learning on mobile device. , I implemented
> Caffe, FastRCNN, and FasterRCNN to Android platform. But I would like to
> remove some layers in different models to speed up and reduce memory usage.
> May I know which layers you remove ? How's the accuracy?
> https://github.com/tzutalin/Android-Object-Detection
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/542.

Hi,

Currently, we only have normal [SGD optimizer](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py#L86). One way to have decaying learning rate is to implement a new Optimizer like adagrad or adam. Would you like to have a try?

Another way to walkaround this is to use the `callback` interface in `model.fit`. Please see [`callback.py`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py) for some examples. You could implement an `epoch_end_callback` and pass it to `model.fit` to adjust learning rate after several epochs. Please let us know what is your choice. Thank you very much.

Best,
Minjie

Hi,

The `NumpySoftmax` is implemented using `numpy` operators, so it could only run on CPU. To use a GPU version softmax, you could use `mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput` to create a symbol and follow the the symbolic execution to run your code. You may want to look at the document [here](https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol.html#symbol-creation-api-reference).

Best,
Minjie

Mingjie, in misc I implemented lr schedule
